text: If you actually make it into the tourist office, you may want something, probably.
I mean, there'll be a reason why you've gone there, perhaps a map or a guide.
Let's recall for a moment.
What is you have?
Vous avez.
How would you say, do you have a guide?
Avez-vous un guide?
Or if you want, you can ask it another way and say, you have a guide?
Vous avez un guide?
Again, guide is spelt the same way, but as is so often the case in French, it's pronounced differently.
It's one of the reasons when people first learn French, they have trouble understanding.
It's not that the words are totally unfamiliar, it's that the pronunciation is.
As you begin to get used to it through this course, you'll find understanding French becomes far easier.
Okay, so you've asked if the person has a guide, a guidebook.
Let's see, how do you think they would reply if they said,
yes, I have a guide of the region.
Of the is...
Deux la.
Deux la.
So, how would you say, I have a guide of the region?
Region ends in ION.
As I said, ION words have come from French, so do your best to pronounce region in a French way.
So, again, how would you say the office of tourism?
Literally, the office of the tourism.
L'office du tourisme.
And how would you say, a guide of the region?
Un guide de la région.
Now, you may well have noticed that I've said the office of the tourism, that the word for of there,
of the, in the office of the tourism, is...
Du.
But that the word for, the words for of the, for of the region are...
Deux la.
And you may be thinking, why?
Why is there this difference?
Well, it's simply that French people like to abbreviate some things, but not necessarily everything.
And what it is, is the word for of is...
Deux.
And it's spelt D-E.
And when you say of the, with a masculine word, the masculine word for the is...
Leux.
Spelt L-E.
When you have a D and a L together, they contract and you end up with this abbreviation,
like in the office of the tourism, which becomes...
Du.
So, let's do that one more time.
The office of the tourism.
L'office du tourisme.
However, if you have a feminine word, and the word for the, for feminine words is...
La.
When you want to say of the, with a feminine word, it doesn't contract.
I mean, you can wonder why.
Why will the masculine contract and why does the feminine not contract?
Well, who knows?
But that's just, that's just how it is.
So, how would you say, again, a guide of the region?
Un guide de la région.
Again, it's not something to worry about hugely.
I wouldn't personally worry about it hugely when speaking.
But it's important to understand when listening why it is that these things change.
Why, for the masculine case, is of the...
Du.
But for the feminine, it's...
De la.
It's simply that one abbreviates, the rule in French is that the masculine one abbreviates
into this new word, which is, which again is...
Du.
Spelt D-U.
But the feminine doesn't.
It just stays as two separate parts.
Again, it's not something to worry about terribly.
But you can keep it in mind.
And it's something you'll be able to check by looking through your booklet at exactly how
these things are written.
This is the end of CD4.
The end of CD4.
